history.content:
IMO - Just let company B know that you won't be able to do the internship this summer, you don't need to provide any details. If they ask why, just tell them your plans have changed, you're sorry for the inconvenience, and you would still be interested in working there full-time, blah blah blah. You don't need to let them know why.

Very doubtful company B will get company A to rescind if these are large companies. Apple is the BigCo I know of that blacklists.

Somebody will probably disagree w/ me.

children.subject: If they're not a tech company then it's hard for me to imagine company A caring at all.
Thanks student answerer. Company B isn't a tech company luckily.
The second company I'm taking an offer at is a FAANG, the company I reneged on is a tech company that works a lot on Java tools.

I also recently reneged. The second company is asking me what I plan to do this summer(cited covid, too). What should I do in this case:

"Hi ___

 

I am so sad to hear you won’t be joining us this summer. I understand these are unprecedented times, so I hope you are safe and healthy.

 

May I ask what you will be pursuing instead this summer? 

 

Best,"

history.content:
Hi all,

I accepted two internship offers for the summer, both at large companies where I don't think it'll devastate them if I'm not there. 

Company A: This is the one I'm pursuing. They have confirmed remote plans for the summer and I accepted this offer probably in early March.

Company B: This is the one I'm reneging. They have no plans to go remote yet, but said the internship will still happen. I accepted this in August. The contract mentions employment at will, so it is legal for me to renege.

How should I go about reneging? I do need to renege eventually. I also don't really care about ruining my relationship with company B, because I don't see myself ever working there.  Is it possible that company B will be able to get my company A offer rescinded for bad behavior?
history.subject: Reneging For Summer
